trans-unit.source: User Defined Routes and IP Forwarding Overview
trans-unit.target: User Defined Routes and IP Forwarding Overview

trans-unit.source: Understanding UDR and IP Forwarding
trans-unit.target: Understanding UDR and IP Forwarding

trans-unit.source: User Defined Routes and IP Forwarding
trans-unit.target: User Defined Routes and IP Forwarding

trans-unit.source: When you add virtual machines (VMs) to a virtual network (VNet) in Azure, you will notice that the VMs are able to communicate with other over the network, automatically.
trans-unit.target: When you add virtual machines (VMs) to a virtual network (VNet) in Azure, you will notice that the VMs are able to communicate with other over the network, automatically.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to specify a gateway, even though the VMs are in different subnets.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to specify a gateway, even though the VMs are in different subnets.

trans-unit.source: The same is true for communication from the VMs to the public Internet, and even to your on-premises network when a hybrid connection from Azure to your own datacenter is present.
trans-unit.target: The same is true for communication from the VMs to the public Internet, and even to your on-premises network when a hybrid connection from Azure to your own datacenter is present.

trans-unit.source: This flow of communication is possible because Azure uses a series of system routes to define how IP traffic flows.
trans-unit.target: This flow of communication is possible because Azure uses a series of system routes to define how IP traffic flows.

trans-unit.source: System routes control the flow of communication in the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: System routes control the flow of communication in the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: From within the same subnet.
trans-unit.target: From within the same subnet.

trans-unit.source: From a subnet to another within a VNet.
trans-unit.target: From a subnet to another within a VNet.

trans-unit.source: From VMs to the Internet.
trans-unit.target: From VMs to the Internet.

trans-unit.source: From a VNet to another VNet through a VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: From a VNet to another VNet through a VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: From a VNet to your on-premises network through a VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: From a VNet to your on-premises network through a VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows a simple setup with a VNet, two subnets, and a few VMs, along with the system routes that allow IP traffic to flow.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows a simple setup with a VNet, two subnets, and a few VMs, along with the system routes that allow IP traffic to flow.

trans-unit.source: System routes in Azure
trans-unit.target: System routes in Azure

trans-unit.source: Although the use of system routes facilitates traffic automatically for your deployment, there are cases in which you want to control the routing of packets through a virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: Although the use of system routes facilitates traffic automatically for your deployment, there are cases in which you want to control the routing of packets through a virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: You can do so by creating user defined routes that specify the next hop for packets flowing to a specific subnet to go to your virtual appliance instead, and enabling IP forwarding for the VM running as the virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: You can do so by creating user defined routes that specify the next hop for packets flowing to a specific subnet to go to your virtual appliance instead, and enabling IP forwarding for the VM running as the virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: The figure below shows an example of user defined routes and IP forwarding to force packets going from a frontend subnet to the Internet to pass through a virtual appliance, and all packets going from the frontend subnet to the backend subnet to go through a different appliance.
trans-unit.target: The figure below shows an example of user defined routes and IP forwarding to force packets going from a frontend subnet to the Internet to pass through a virtual appliance, and all packets going from the frontend subnet to the backend subnet to go through a different appliance.

trans-unit.source: Notice that traffic from the backend subnet to the frontend subnet is still going through the system route, bypassing the appliance.
trans-unit.target: Notice that traffic from the backend subnet to the frontend subnet is still going through the system route, bypassing the appliance.

trans-unit.source: System routes in Azure
trans-unit.target: System routes in Azure

trans-unit.source: Routing
trans-unit.target: Routing

trans-unit.source: Packets are routed over a TCP/IP network based on a route table defined at each node on the physical network.
trans-unit.target: Packets are routed over a TCP/IP network based on a route table defined at each node on the physical network.

trans-unit.source: A route table is a collection of individual routes used to decide where to forward packets based on the destination IP address.
trans-unit.target: A route table is a collection of individual routes used to decide where to forward packets based on the destination IP address.

trans-unit.source: A route consists of the following:
trans-unit.target: A route consists of the following:

trans-unit.source: **Address Prefix**.
trans-unit.target: **Address Prefix**.

trans-unit.source: The destination CIDR to which the route applies, such as 10.1.0.0/16.
trans-unit.target: The destination CIDR to which the route applies, such as 10.1.0.0/16.

trans-unit.source: **Next hop type**.
trans-unit.target: **Next hop type**.

trans-unit.source: The type of Azure hop the packet should be sent to.
trans-unit.target: The type of Azure hop the packet should be sent to.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are:
trans-unit.target: Possible values are:

trans-unit.source: **Local**.
trans-unit.target: **Local**.

trans-unit.source: Represents the local virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Represents the local virtual network.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, the route for each subnet in the route table will have a next hop value of *Local*.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you have two subnets, 10.1.0.0/16 and 10.2.0.0/16 in the same virtual network, the route for each subnet in the route table will have a next hop value of *Local*.

trans-unit.source: **VPN Gateway**.
trans-unit.target: **VPN Gateway**.

trans-unit.source: Represents an Azure S2S VPN Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Represents an Azure S2S VPN Gateway.

trans-unit.source: **Internet**.
trans-unit.target: **Internet**.

trans-unit.source: Represents the default Internet gateway provided by the Azure Infrastructure
trans-unit.target: Represents the default Internet gateway provided by the Azure Infrastructure

trans-unit.source: **Virtual Appliance**.
trans-unit.target: **Virtual Appliance**.

trans-unit.source: Represents a virtual appliance you added to your Azure virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Represents a virtual appliance you added to your Azure virtual network.

trans-unit.source: **NULL**.
trans-unit.target: **NULL**.

trans-unit.source: Represents a black hole.
trans-unit.target: Represents a black hole.

trans-unit.source: Packets forwarded to a black hole will not be forwarded at all.
trans-unit.target: Packets forwarded to a black hole will not be forwarded at all.

trans-unit.source: **Nexthop Value**.
trans-unit.target: **Nexthop Value**.

trans-unit.source: The next hop value contains the IP address packets should be forwarded to.
trans-unit.target: The next hop value contains the IP address packets should be forwarded to.

trans-unit.source: Next hop values are only allowed in routes where the next hop type is *Virtual Appliance*.
trans-unit.target: Next hop values are only allowed in routes where the next hop type is *Virtual Appliance*.

trans-unit.source: System Routes
trans-unit.target: System Routes

trans-unit.source: Every subnet created in a virtual network is automatically associated with a route table that contains the following system route rules:
trans-unit.target: Every subnet created in a virtual network is automatically associated with a route table that contains the following system route rules:

trans-unit.source: **Local Vnet Rule**: This rule is automatically created for every subnet in a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: **Local Vnet Rule**: This rule is automatically created for every subnet in a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: It specifies that there is a direct link between the VMs in the VNet and there is no intermediate next hop.
trans-unit.target: It specifies that there is a direct link between the VMs in the VNet and there is no intermediate next hop.

trans-unit.source: **On-premises Rule**: This rule applies to all traffic destined to the on-premises address range and uses VPN gateway as the next hop destination.
trans-unit.target: **On-premises Rule**: This rule applies to all traffic destined to the on-premises address range and uses VPN gateway as the next hop destination.

trans-unit.source: **Internet Rule**: This rule handles all traffic destined to the public Internet and uses the infrastructure internet gateway as the next hop for all traffic destined to the Internet.
trans-unit.target: **Internet Rule**: This rule handles all traffic destined to the public Internet and uses the infrastructure internet gateway as the next hop for all traffic destined to the Internet.

trans-unit.source: User Defined Routes
trans-unit.target: User Defined Routes

trans-unit.source: For most environments you will only need the system routes already defined by Azure.
trans-unit.target: For most environments you will only need the system routes already defined by Azure.

trans-unit.source: However, you may need to create a route table and add one or more routes in specific cases, such as:
trans-unit.target: However, you may need to create a route table and add one or more routes in specific cases, such as:

trans-unit.source: Force tunneling to the Internet via your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: Force tunneling to the Internet via your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: Use of virtual appliances in your Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: Use of virtual appliances in your Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: In the scenarios above, you will have to create a route table and add user defined routes to it.
trans-unit.target: In the scenarios above, you will have to create a route table and add user defined routes to it.

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple route tables, and the same route table can be associated to one or more subnets.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple route tables, and the same route table can be associated to one or more subnets.

trans-unit.source: And each subnet can only be associated to a single route table.
trans-unit.target: And each subnet can only be associated to a single route table.

trans-unit.source: All VMs and cloud services in a subnet use the route table associated to that subnet.
trans-unit.target: All VMs and cloud services in a subnet use the route table associated to that subnet.

trans-unit.source: Subnets rely on system routes until a route table is associated to the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Subnets rely on system routes until a route table is associated to the subnet.

trans-unit.source: Once an association exists, routing is done based on Longest Prefix Match (LPM) among both user defined routes and system routes.
trans-unit.target: Once an association exists, routing is done based on Longest Prefix Match (LPM) among both user defined routes and system routes.

trans-unit.source: If there is more than one route with the same LPM match then a route is selected based on its origin in the following order:
trans-unit.target: If there is more than one route with the same LPM match then a route is selected based on its origin in the following order:

trans-unit.source: User defined route
trans-unit.target: User defined route

trans-unit.source: BGP route (when ExpressRoute is used)
trans-unit.target: BGP route (when ExpressRoute is used)

trans-unit.source: System route
trans-unit.target: System route

trans-unit.source: To learn how to create user defined routes, see [How to Create Routes and Enable IP Forwarding in Azure](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-manage-routes).
trans-unit.target: To learn how to create user defined routes, see [How to Create Routes and Enable IP Forwarding in Azure](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-manage-routes).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] User defined routes are only applied to Azure VMs and cloud services.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] User defined routes are only applied to Azure VMs and cloud services.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you want to add a firewall virtual appliance between your on-premises network and Azure, you will have to create a user defined route for your Azure route tables that forward all traffic going to the on-premises address space to the virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you want to add a firewall virtual appliance between your on-premises network and Azure, you will have to create a user defined route for your Azure route tables that forward all traffic going to the on-premises address space to the virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: However, incoming traffic from the on-premises address space will flow through your VPN gateway or ExpressRoute circuit straight to the Azure environment, bypassing the virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: However, incoming traffic from the on-premises address space will flow through your VPN gateway or ExpressRoute circuit straight to the Azure environment, bypassing the virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: BGP Routes
trans-unit.target: BGP Routes

trans-unit.source: If you have an ExpressRoute connection between your on-premises network and Azure, you can enable BGP to propagate routes from your on-premises network to Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you have an ExpressRoute connection between your on-premises network and Azure, you can enable BGP to propagate routes from your on-premises network to Azure.

trans-unit.source: These BGP routes are used in the same way as system routes and user defined routes in each Azure subnet.
trans-unit.target: These BGP routes are used in the same way as system routes and user defined routes in each Azure subnet.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [ExpressRoute Introduction](../expressroute-introduction).
trans-unit.target: For more information see [ExpressRoute Introduction](../expressroute-introduction).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] You can configure your Azure environment to use force tunneling through your on-premises network by creating a user defined route for subnet 0.0.0.0/0 that uses the VPN gateway as the next hop.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] You can configure your Azure environment to use force tunneling through your on-premises network by creating a user defined route for subnet 0.0.0.0/0 that uses the VPN gateway as the next hop.

trans-unit.source: However, this only works if you are using a VPN gateway, not ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: However, this only works if you are using a VPN gateway, not ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: For ExpressRoute, forced tunneling is configured through BGP.
trans-unit.target: For ExpressRoute, forced tunneling is configured through BGP.

trans-unit.source: IP Forwarding
trans-unit.target: IP Forwarding

trans-unit.source: As describe above, one of the main reasons to create a user defined route is to forward traffic to a virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: As describe above, one of the main reasons to create a user defined route is to forward traffic to a virtual appliance.

trans-unit.source: A virtual appliance is nothing more than a VM that runs an application used to handle network traffic in some way, such as a firewall or a NAT device.
trans-unit.target: A virtual appliance is nothing more than a VM that runs an application used to handle network traffic in some way, such as a firewall or a NAT device.

trans-unit.source: This virtual appliance VM must be able to receive incoming traffic that is not addressed to itself.
trans-unit.target: This virtual appliance VM must be able to receive incoming traffic that is not addressed to itself.

trans-unit.source: To allow a VM to receive traffic addressed to other destinations, you must enable IP Forwarding for the VM.
trans-unit.target: To allow a VM to receive traffic addressed to other destinations, you must enable IP Forwarding for the VM.

trans-unit.source: This is an Azure setting, not a setting in the guest operating system.
trans-unit.target: This is an Azure setting, not a setting in the guest operating system.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to enable IP forwarding for a VM in Azure, see [How to Create Routes and Enable IP Forwarding in Azure](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-Manage-IP-Forwarding).
trans-unit.target: To learn how to enable IP forwarding for a VM in Azure, see [How to Create Routes and Enable IP Forwarding in Azure](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-Manage-IP-Forwarding).

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Learn how to [create routes](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-manage-routes) and associate them to subnets.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to [create routes](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-manage-routes) and associate them to subnets.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to [enable IP forwarding](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-Manage-IP-Forwarding) for a VM running a virtual appliance.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to [enable IP forwarding](../virtual-networks-udr-how-to#How-to-Manage-IP-Forwarding) for a VM running a virtual appliance.
